Chan knows that local water sources require boiling before consumption and boiling water consumes natural and financial resources. The water filter Toun purchased will increase her family’s disposable income by substantially decreasing money spent to buy charcoal and time spent to forage for firewood. The filter also eliminates the need to purchase bottled water if it is available.    

Chan is excited that the filter was purchased on an affordable payment schedule and the filter is guaranteed for two years – so she and her group can continue to receive the many benefits of clean water for many months to come.

loans.use: to purchase TerraClear water filters so they can have access to safe drinking water.

The water filter Tui purchased will increase her family’s disposable income by substantially decreasing money spent to buy charcoal or forage for firewood. The filter also eliminates the need to purchase bottled water if it is available.    

Tui is excited that the filter was purchased on an affordable payment schedule and the filter is guaranteed for two years – so she and her group can continue to receive the many benefits of clean water for many months to come.

loans.use: to purchase TerraClear water filters so they can have access to safe drinking water.

loans.name: Carlos Humberto

texts.es: Carlos de 48 años de edad viven casa propia con su compañera de vida y sus dos hijos, el se dedica a realizar viajes en su taxi desde hace 15 años, tiene muchos clientes que lo prefieren por la responsabilidad que tiene a la hora de manejar, con lo que obtiene de su trabajo logra solventar los gastos que se le presentan en su hogar, el está solicitando un crédito para la compra de llantas y darle mantenimiento a su taxi ya que esa es su única fuente de trabajo y poder tener mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Carlos is 48 years old and lives in his own home along with his life companion and their two children. He has been making trips with his taxi for the past 15 years. Carlos has many customers who prefer to do business with him because he is responsible when he drives. With the income he earns from his work, he is able to cover his household expenses.

Carlos is requesting a loan in order to buy tires and pay for the maintenance of his taxi. This is his only job and it allows him to have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy tires and pay for the maintenance of his taxi.

loans.name: Paula

texts.es: Paula tiene 56 años de edad y vive en casa propia con su grupo familiar, ella posee desde hace 7 años una pequeña tienda ubicada en su lugar de residencia, tiene muchos clientes por los buenos precios y la amabilidad que tiene a la hora de vender, ella está solicitando un crédito para poder comprar más sopas, huevos, granos básicos, refrescos, golosinas, pan dulce, etc. y así poder tener mejores ingresos para una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Paula is 56 years old and lives in her own home along with her family. For the past seven years, she has managed a small store from her place of residence. She has many customers because of the good prices and the friendliness that she displays when conducting sales.

Paula is requesting a loan in order to buy more soups, eggs, basic grains, soft drinks, snack foods, sweet bread, and other products so that she can earn more income. As a result, she will have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy soups, eggs, basic grains, soft drinks, snack foods, sweet bread, and other products.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a married man. He has seven children. He describes himself as capable and operates a farm where he grows potatoes. He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are of all types. 

Stephen describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient capital. He will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy farm inputs to enable him to increase production. His business goal is to be prosperous within five years. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy farm inputs to increase his production of potatoes.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is a 51-year-old widow and a mother of four children. Her husband died three years ago. Thelma is a banana dealer and has a sari-sari (general store) business. She has been in business for 20 years, and she is thankful it is still going. Through her income from her business, Thelma was able to provide for all her children's needs when they were attending school. Now, all her children are working. 

Thelma still wants to continue to run the business to support her sister’s children's allowances for their education. Therefore, Thelma is requesting a loan of P50,000 to buy groceries to sell in villages. She will also use the loan to buy bananas for import to Manila. Thelma doesn’t want to lose her hope that someday her nephews and nieces will finish their studies and will have a better future.

loans.use: to buy groceries to sell in villages.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is a married woman. She has three children. She describes herself as ambitious. 

Regina operates a farm where she grows potatoes. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are individuals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. She will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy farm inputs to enable her to increase production. 

She hopes that in the future, she will have a successful business. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs to increase production of potatoes.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a married man. He has two children. He describes himself as focused. 

John operates a transport business in which he transports customers using his motorcycle. He has been involved in this business for three years. His business is located in a market place and his primary customers are the general public. He describes his biggest business challenge to be high fuel prices. He will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy another motorcycle. He hopes that in the future he will have a recognised transport firm. 

This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy another motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet is a married woman. She has four children. She describes herself as determined. 

Violet operates a retail business where she sells soft drinks. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is in a viable location and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. She will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of soft drinks and juice. 

She hopes that in the future, she will be able to educate her children and live a good life. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the anticipated profits to generate wealth and create employment.

loans.use: buy more stock of soft drinks and juice.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a Kiva borrower. She has four children. She describes herself as honest and friendly. She operates a tailoring shop where she makes clothes. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a marketable place and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge as price fluctuation. She will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more tailoring materials and to repair the tailoring machine. 

Maria's business goal is to grow into a large fashion design shop within five years. She hopes that in the future she will educate her children and live a good life. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the anticipated profits to start other income-generating activities.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tailoring materials and to repair tailoring machine.

loans.name: Peris

texts.en:
Peris is a single woman. She has four children. She describes herself as resilient. 

Peris operates a farm where she keeps cows and poultry. She has been involved in this business for 17 years. Her primary customers are individuals. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more cows and poultry. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: buy more cows and poultry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy more stocks of meat

loans.name: Laura

texts.es:
Laura tiene 46 años de edad vive con su sobrina en Guaranda provincia de Bolivar, pertenece a la Ventanilla Rural Los Emprendedores Bolivarenses.

Ella se dedica a la venta de comida, solicita el credito para la compra de una cocina industrial ya que necesita para realizar las ventas de la comida rapida por que la que tenia se deterioro, gracias a la ayuda del prestamo podra mejorar su negocio su sueño es terminar de construir su casita.
En su tiempo libre le gusta dedicarse a la casa y cuidar de los animales que cria.
texts.en:
Laura is 46 years old and lives with her niece in Guaranda in Bolivar Province. She is a member of the Communal Bank named “Los Emprendedores Bolivarenses”.

Laura sells food and is requesting a loan in order to buy an industrial stove. She needs this for her business of selling fast food because the stove she currently has is not functioning. Thanks to the help of this loan, she will be able to improve her business. Her dream is to finish the construction of her house.

In her free time, Laura enjoys being at home and taking care of the animals she raises.

loans.use: to buy an industrial stove.

loans.name: Patimah

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! Now it's time for you to meet one of Ruma's agents, Patimah. Patimah and her husband live in a family home in Bogor, a suburban area located about an hour from Jakarta, the capital city. They have two children; the older one is already at university, and the younger one is still in elementary school. Patimah owns several businesses, such as running an internet cafe called "Warung Internet" (or "WarNet" for short), offering household items on installment, selling mobile phone airtime credits, and processing bill payments for her customers. 

Patimah joined Ruma in 2013 and this is the second time that she has applied for a loan from Kiva. The previous loan helped her to process more mobile phone airtime credits for her community and she therefore thanks all the lenders.

With support from Ruma staff, Patimah sees that her business has improved. Now, as the business grows, she is hoping to receive another working capital loan from Kiva. She will use the capital to provide more mobile payment services to her community, especially on weekends. Knowing about its importance, your loan will be very useful in helping Patimah to improve her business and, accordingly, helping her community which needs access to such services. She will be thankful for your kind and endless support. Patimah is sitting in the above photo.

loans.use: to provide more mobile payment services for her community

loans.name: Sabiana

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Sabiana works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling fish. Sabiana is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to buy fish nets and other materials needed for her fishing business.

Sabiana has been sustaining her business activities through her past eight loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fish nets and other materials needed for her business.

loans.name: Metusela

texts.en:
Metusela is 57 years old and married with two children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Metusela runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell. She has been in this business for five years and sells a variety of items such as noodles, rice sardines and other groceries. 

In the future Metusela would like to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Nyagika '2011' Group

texts.en:
Joseph is 47 years old, is married and has four children. He is a member of the Nyagika 2011 Group and describes himself as ambitious. Joseph practises mixed farming by growing vegetables such as cabbages, kale and potatoes, and dairy farming. Apart from farming, he sells kale in the local market. 

Joseph is borrowing a loan to add more stock to his kale-selling business thus earning more income from improved sales. He hopes this will help him support his family by providing better clothing and paying his children's school fees.

Joseph is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for financial support. He is the man holding an envelope in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy more stock of kale to sell and therefore earn more income.

loans.name: Witeithie Uteithio Women Group

texts.en:
In 2010, Witeithie Uteithio Women Group joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in order to benefit from training in enterprise management. The group has been trained on prudent financial management which has assisted them to improve their livelihood. The group is also involved in activities such as table banking and merry go round.

The lady raising her hand is Alice. She is married and blessed with three children. Alice works by farming maize, beans and vegetables, and also does poultry farming. She is borrowing the Kiva loan to buy poultry feed and build a better shed for her poultry. This will ensure that she maintains a steady supply of chickens and eggs in the market and thus a stable and consistent income.

Alice appreciates Kiva's help for this financial intervention as she will be able to take care of her needs.

loans.use: To buy poultry feed and construct a better poultry shed that will facilitate improved household income.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Eunice. She is 63 years old, married and living with her husband who supports her to raise their family. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013 and has benefited from the group management, savings mobilization, entrepreneurship and financial management training courses.

Eunice practices mixed farming of potatoes, cabbages, peas and rearing sheep. Her training has improved her farming methods and production. She is asking for a loan to further expand her farming enterprise by buying certified potato seeds and manure. She hopes that the Kiva loan will help her boost her business and make better returns to help her in providing school fees for the children and better clothing.

Eunice is grateful for Kiva and its lenders for the great support.

loans.use: to buy certified seeds and manure to expand  her farming business.

loans.name: Hadpho Group

texts.en: Fa is excited that the filter was available on an affordable, payment plan.  Fa and her group, along with other villagers, participated in a village meeting where they discussed the costs of treating local water supplies.  Charcoal, firewood, even bottled water were discussed and priced out over two years.  The water filter Fa and her group purchased is guaranteed for two years but is known to function for up to five years.  Fa and her group also discussed the cost of medical care for water-borne disease. And after totaling up the costs, Fa and her group recognized the substantial financial savings the water filter will have for them and their families.

loans.use: to purchase a TerraClear water filter so she can have access to safe drinking water.

loans.name: Phoukham Group

texts.en: Kongherr’s village sources much of the drinking water from local wells, streams, and collected rainwater.  These sources of water are not safe to drink without treatment by boiling.  Kongherr and her group are excited that the filter was available on a payment plan that made it much more affordable.  Treating drinking water requires cash and time, which now she can shift to other pursuits.  Kongherr and her village also understands the impact unsafe drinking water has on their family’s budgets. The filter is guaranteed for two years; within this two years, filter users, like Kongherr’s family, identify a substantial decrease in illness and associated medical costs.

loans.use: to purchase TerraClear water filters so she can have access to safe drinking water.

loans.name: Phonsee Group

texts.en: Khamsee understands the difference the water filter can make for her family and for her group’s families.  Khamsee knows that local water sources require boiling before consumption and boiling water consumes natural and financial resources.  The water filter Khamsee purchased will increase her family’s disposable income by substantially decreasing money spent to buy charcoal or decreasing the time and cost of foraging for firewood.  The filter also eliminates the need to purchase bottled water if it is available. Khamsee is excited that the filter was purchased on an affordable payment schedule and the filter is guaranteed for two years – so she and her group can continue to receive the many benefits of clean water for many months to come.

loans.use: to purchase TerraClear water filters so she can have access to safe drinking water.
